gov.usgs.traveltime

Class TauUtil

  • java.lang.Object
    • gov.usgs.traveltime.TauUtil

  • public class TauUtil
extends java.lang.Object
    Utility methods for the travel-time package.
    Author:
    Ray Buland

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static double ASSOCFACTOR
      The association window for theoretical phases will be the association factor times the spread.
      static double azimuth
      Receiver azimuth relative to the source in degrees clockwise from north (available after calling delAz).

      static double projLon
      Longitude in degrees projected from an epicenter by a distance and azimuth.
      static double WINDOWMIN
      In any case, don't let the association window get smaller than the minimum window size no matter how well observed the phase is.

      • MAXDELPN

        public static final double MAXDELPN
        Maximum credible Pn source-receiver distance in degrees. Note that these maximum regional phase distances are mostly needed for RSTT. Because of the nature of the algorithm, there are no inherent distance limits for any of the phases.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • MAXDELSN

        public static final double MAXDELSN
        Maximum credible Sn source-receiver distance in degrees. Note that there is a short Sn branch in the WUS model at more than 40 degrees that appears to be an artifact of layering the WUS crust on top of the AK135 mantle.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • WINDOWMIN

        public static final double WINDOWMIN
        In any case, don't let the association window get smaller than the minimum window size no matter how well observed the phase is. The larger window is needed when the location is poor.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • NoCorr

        public static final boolean NoCorr

      • setUseless

        public static boolean setUseless(java.lang.String phCode)
        Algorithmically identify phases that are unlikely to be useful for earthquake location. These are crustal phases that always appear in coda of the first arriving P or S phases.
        Parameters:
        phCode - Phase code
        Returns:
        True if phase is in the crustal P or S coda

      • arrivalType

        public static char arrivalType(java.lang.String phCode)
        Classify seismic phases according to their wave type at the receiver.
        Parameters:
        phCode - Phase code
        Returns:
        'P' for a p-wave, 'S' for an s-wave, 'L' for an Lg, and 'R' for an LR.

      • filterDef

        public static void filterDef(java.util.ArrayList<TTimeData> tTimes)
        By default, filter out phases of the same name that are so close in time as to be useless. This is particularly useful when there are small instabilities in the tau interpolation.
        Parameters:
        tTimes - An array list of travel-time objects

      • modObserv

        public static void modObserv(java.util.ArrayList<TTimeData> tTimes)
        Modify the of observability of phases closely following other phases (in time). This is a real seat-of-the-pants hack. The problem is that the proximity of phases in time depends on depth, but the statistics include all depths (corrected to surface focus).
        Parameters:
        tTimes - An array list of travel-time objects

      • filterBack

        public static void filterBack(java.util.ArrayList<TTimeData> tTimes)
        Optionally, all seismic back branches can be filtered out. Triplication back branches confuse the Locator, so this filter removes all secondary phases of the same name no matter how big the arrival time differences.
        Parameters:
        tTimes - An array list of travel-time objects

      • filterTect

        public static void filterTect(java.util.ArrayList<TTimeData> tTimes)
        Optionally, Pb and Sb can be renamed Pg and Sg respectively. By default, the travel-time calculations are done for continental cratons where there may be clear Pb (P*) and Sb (S*) phases. However, these just annoy the seismic analysts in tectonic areas where they are rarely if ever observed. The crude hack implemented here is to rename Pb and Sb to Pg and Sg respectively. This has the effect of pretending that the modeled Conrad discontinuity is a smooth transition and that Pg and Sg may turn all the way to the Moho. Note that this may create new back branches, so it should be run before the default or back branch filters.
        Parameters:
        tTimes - An array list of travel-time objects

      • modCanUse

        public static void modCanUse(java.util.ArrayList<TTimeData> tTimes)
        By default, canUse only reflects phase types that make sense to use in an earthquake Location. However, phases can't be used if they have no statistics either. Setting canUse to reflect both conditions makes it easier for the Locator.
        Parameters:
        tTimes - An array list of travel-time objects

      • filterMisc

        public static void filterMisc(java.util.ArrayList<TTimeData> tTimes,
                              double delta)
        Apply miscellaneous filters to get rid of extraneous phases.
        Parameters:
        tTimes - An array list of travel-time objects
        delta - Source-receiver distance in degrees

      • geoCen

        public static double geoCen(double latitude)
        Compute the geocentric co-latitude.
        Parameters:
        latitude - Geographical latitude in degrees
        Returns:
        Geocentric co-latitude in degrees

        public static double geoLat(double coLat)
        Compute the geographic latitude.
        Parameters:
        coLat - Geocentric co-latitude in degrees
        Returns:
        Geographic latitude in degrees

      • delAz

        public static double delAz(double eqLat,
                           double eqLon,
                           double staLat,
                           double staLon)
        An historically significant subroutine from deep time (1962)! This routine was written by Bob Engdahl in Fortran (actually in the days before subroutines) and beaten into it's current Fortran form by Ray Buland in the early 1980s. It's optimized with respect to computing sines and cosines (probably still worthwhile) and it computes exactly what's needed--no more, no less. This (much more horrible) alternate form to the delAz in LocUtil is much closer to Engdahl's original. It is needed to avoid a build path cycle. Note that the azimuth is returned in static variable azimuth.
        Parameters:
        eqLat - Geographic source latitude in degrees
        eqLon - Source longitude in degrees
        staLat - Geographic station latitude in degrees
        staLon - Station longitude in degrees
        Returns:
        Distance (delta) in degrees

      • projLat

        public static double projLat(double latitude,
                             double longitude,
                             double delta,
                             double azimuth)
        Project an epicenter using distance and azimuth. Used in finding the bounce point for a surface reflected seismic phase. Note that the projected longitude is returned in static variable projLon.
        Parameters:
        latitude - Geographic epicenter latitude in degrees
        longitude - Epicenter longitude in degrees
        delta - Distance to project in degrees
        azimuth - Azimuth to project in degrees
        Returns:
        Projected geographic latitude in degrees

      • topoCorr

        public static double topoCorr(double elev,
                              double vel,
                              double dTdD)
        Elevation correction.
        Parameters:
        elev - Elevation in kilometers
        vel - Velocity in kilometers/second
        dTdD - Ray parameter in seconds/kilometers
        Returns:
        Elevation correction in seconds

      • biLinear

        public static double biLinear(double var0,
                              double var1,
                              GenIndex val0,
                              GenIndex val1,
                              double[][] grid)
        Bilinear interpolation. The indices are such that val[ind] < var <= val[ind+1]. The two dimensional grid of values to be interpolated has values val0 associated with it's first index and values val1 associated with it's second index.
        Parameters:
        var0 - First variable
        var1 - Second variable
        val0 - Value array for the first grid index
        val1 - Value array for the second grid index
        grid - Two dimensional array of values to be interpolated
        Returns:
        Interpolated value

      • biLinear

        public static double biLinear(double var0,
                              double var1,
                              GenIndex val0,
                              GenIndex val1,
                              short[][] grid)
        Bilinear interpolation. The indices are such that val[ind] < var <= val[ind+1]. The two dimensional grid of values to be interpolated has values val0 associated with it's first index and values val1 associated with it's second index.
        Parameters:
        var0 - First variable
        var1 - Second variable
        val0 - Value array for the first grid index
        val1 - Value array for the second grid index
        grid - Two dimensional array of values to be interpolated
        Returns:
        Interpolated value
